title: 106_s1346
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Office of Advocacy Act". Congress acknowledges the burden of excessive regulations on small businesses and the reluctance of Federal agencies to comply with statutory requirements, highlighting the importance of the Office of Advocacy in advocating for small businesses. The Office of Advocacy ensures agencies comply with statutory obligations to support small businesses, maintaining independence for effective advocacy and adequate resources for research on regulatory impacts. The Office of Advocacy provides valuable advice to Congress and executive branch agencies on behalf of small businesses, utilizing its research, information, and expertise. The Office of Advocacy provides advice to Congress and executive branch agencies for small businesses. The Office of Advocacy ensures its independence and financial resources to advocate for small businesses. It reports to key committees and the Small Business Administration to keep them informed about issues affecting small businesses. It also authorizes appropriations separately. The Office of Advocacy ensures independence and financial resources to advocate for small businesses. It reports to key committees and the Small Business Administration to keep them informed about issues affecting small businesses. It also authorizes separate appropriations for the Office, allows reporting to the President and Congress on agency compliance, and enhances the Office's role as per chapter 6 of title 5, United States Code. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section, SEC. 32, establishing the Office of Advocacy. The Small Business Act is amended to establish the Office of Advocacy, with the Chief Counsel appointed by the President from civilian life. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy shall be appointed by the President from civilian life, with Senate approval, based on fitness for the role. The appointee cannot have been an officer or employee of the Small Business Administration in the previous 5 years. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can be removed from office. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can be removed by the President, who must notify Congress 30 days before the removal. Each appropriation request must include a separate request for the Office. The Office's primary function is to examine the role of small businesses in the US economy. The curr_chunk discusses the importance of small businesses in the US economy, highlighting their role in improving competition, economic and social mobility, restraining inflation, spurring production, expanding employment opportunities, increasing productivity, promoting exports, stimulating innovation and entrepreneurship, and bringing new products to the marketplace. It also mentions assessing the effectiveness of Federal subsidy and assistance programs for small businesses. The curr_chunk focuses on reducing government regulation and altering the tax structure to benefit small businesses. The curr_chunk discusses studying financial markets to meet small business credit needs, determining financial resource availability, and recommending methods for delivering financial assistance to minority and women-owned enterprises. The curr_chunk focuses on evaluating efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, making recommendations for their development, and suggesting measures for creating an inclusive business environment. The curr_chunk outlines recommendations for creating an environment where all businesses can compete effectively and expand, determining criteria for defining small businesses, and submitting reports to relevant committees. The Office serves as a focal point for receiving complaints and suggestions regarding small business policies and activities of the Administration and other government departments. The Office of the Federal Government assists small businesses by counseling on resolving issues with the government, proposing policy changes, and representing small business interests to other federal agencies. The Office of the Federal Government assists small businesses by enlisting cooperation from public and private agencies to disseminate information about government programs beneficial to small businesses. They also carry out responsibilities under chapter 6 of title 5, United States Code. The Chief Counsel of the Office may appoint additional personnel without following civil service laws, and set their compensation without adhering to certain regulations. The Chief Counsel of the Office has the authority to appoint personnel and set their compensation rates, with limitations not exceeding the maximum rate for a GS-15 position. Additionally, the Chief Counsel can procure temporary services as authorized by section 3109. The Chief Counsel of the Office can appoint personnel and set compensation rates within authorized limits. They can also consult with experts in various financial fields and individuals with expertise in regulation, law, economics, or finance. The Chief Counsel of the Office can appoint personnel, set compensation rates, consult with experts, and use the services of the National Advisory Council to appoint advisory boards or committees as necessary. They can also hold hearings at appropriate times and places. The Administrator shall provide the Office with office space, equipment, supplies, and communication facilities as needed. The Chief Counsel may obtain information from Federal agencies. The Chief Counsel may obtain necessary information directly from Federal departments or agencies. Annual reports must be submitted to the President and various committees on a regular basis. The Chief Counsel may prepare and publish reports on agency compliance with title 5, United States Code. No report shall be submitted to any department or agency before being sent to the President and relevant committees. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy may prepare and publish reports on agency compliance with title 5, United States Code. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Office to carry out this section. Title II of Public Law 94-305 is repealed, and the incumbent Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is specified. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration will continue to serve in that position after the enactment of this Act. The Act was passed by the Senate on November 5, 1999, with Gary Sisco as the Secretary.
